This SAP CodeJam event is on the topic of the ABAP Cloud, and specifically introduces attendees to ABAP Cloud and the ABAP RESTful Application Programming Model. ABAP Cloud is the ABAP-based development model for S/4HANA Cloud, S/4HANA on-premise, and SAP BTP, ABAP environment.

Learn how to use proven and new technologies, such as Core Data Services (CDS) and behavior definition and implementation languages, to build SAP Fiori apps and OData services on any of the ABAP Cloud options. In this hands-on experience, developers will create their first ABAP applications using ABAP Cloud, expose and consume services via HTTP, and explore the ABAP RESTful Application Programming Model.

This is an in-person event only (not virtual) and is planned for Thursday 22nd January 2026 in Hyderabad from 09:00 - 16:00 IST. The language and content of the event will be in English.

entry.title: Impact of de-globalization on instance strategy
entry.content:
Summary

With geopolitical tensions growing and governments becoming more protectionistic in policy-making, enterprises are preparing for a more localized, de-globalized world. This article describes observations from the SAP Transformation Hub on the impact on instance strategy and gives advice on what enterprises should consider when making decisions on their instance strategy.

 

Decision making on Instance Strategy

SAP has a proven methodology and best practice criteria that have helped hundreds of enterprise customers of all sizes to make decisions on their instance strategy. The set of criteria is explained in this blog and a whitepaper that describes considerations for splitting and consolidating instances is available for download here. Due to the increase of relevancy and growing interest in de-globalization, 2 new criteria have been added recently: geopolitical risks and legal compliance.

 

What aspects on de-globalization should enterprises consider? 

1. Enterprises with multinational operations are confronted with increasing geopolitical risks impacting their IT landscape. Proper risk management requires examining different scenarios from sanctions and export control for technology, data espionage, control cross border data flow to sudden disruption of data transfer. Changes in geopolitical situations may require re-assessing instance strategy options. The resilience of the architecture to sustain events needs to be looked at. Drawing on enterprise architecture dimensions enhances the assessment of instance strategy in the context of geopolitical risks

    1. Business Architecture: In times of crisis, countries may try to protect their economy by regulations and limitations such as mandatory business operations completely in the country and control data residency and flow. Consequently, enterprises need to be able to operate critical capabilities locally to ensure business continuity. Turning to business architecture helps evaluate which capabilities are critical for operations in countries at risk. If risk assessment concludes to proactive risk mitigation, these capabilities could be encapsulated and supported by local ringfenced building blocks, e.g. for order-to-cash on a local ERP while consolidating local finance in a corporate system.
    2. Application Architecture: for countries-at-risk, the criticality of operations running on global applications needs to be evaluated. A local instance may be required, or local data persistence in the form of archiving may need to be established. To achieve the desired level of resilience in critical areas, applications need to be duplicated and deployed locally to ensure continuity in times of crisis.
    3. Data Architecture: Questions that guide towards a proper assessment of the risk can include: Which types of data are being processed? How critical is the data? Where does the data flow and reside physically? What are the security and privacy measures implemented? Is there end-to-end encryption? Can I afford exposing my global data to governmental intelligence services? What would happen if the data would suddenly not be available? How difficult are changes to data provisioning?
    4. Technical Architecture: Relevant questions for assessing the risk include: Where are my data centres located? Are there sufficient security measures implemented in data centre operations? Where are my cloud vendors located? Under which jurisdiction do they operate?

It is impossible for global acting enterprises to be completely free from geopolitical dependencies. The more transparency into enterprise architecture is available in all dimensions, though, the easier it is to identify and mitigate risk.

 

2. An increasing number of new laws and regulations are being issued by governments all over the world around data protection and cybersecurity, which forces global acting enterprises to adapt.  Prime examples of recent years include the General Data Protection Regulation (GDPR) in the EU, the General Data Protection Law (LGPD) in Brazil or the China Personal Information Protection Law (PIPL) in China, which provides similar measures.

Usually, governments give enterprises time to become compliant with new laws. Enterprises first need to interpret and determine what it means for their operations before implementing concrete measures in their systems.

 

Trends in Customer's decision making

In the past, we have observed a trend across industries for consolidation of instances. Driven by the availability of scaling infrastructure, large enterprises with global operations were able to realize considerable business benefits by harmonizing business processes and simplifying landscapes. Those enterprises whose business is truly global in nature were able to benefit from capabilities such as single source of truth for customer, inventory, etc. as well as more LoB specific functions such as global supply chain planning. The trend towards consolidation in general continues but we have observed situations where customers have deviated from plans of a single global instance and shifted to a more modular architecture driven by considerations on de-globalization. A controlled decoupling of critical applications is an approach enterprises are following to better manage risks. The higher the geopolitical risk, the more attractive are sovereign cloud options which are now evolving fast in response to customer demand.

 

Conclusion

Decisions on instance strategy have a large impact on transformation programs and require a holistic perspective with considerations on business strategy, IT operations, deployment and technology. While aspects on deglobalization gain in importance, enterprises need to integrate geopolitical risk and legal compliance when making instance strategy decisions.

While implementing laws and regulation can be planned, geopolitical risk requires a different treatment. Landscape options should be evaluated considering resilience towards mitigating geopolitical risks and how regulation on data privacy, protection and localization can be facilitated. Landscape options providing higher agility and resilience towards possible geopolitical disruptions and those that are easier to adapt to new regulation are becoming more attractive.

Use Case:

Any guidance or documentation references would be greatly appreciated.
Thank you in advance for your help!
Best regards,

entry.title: üáÆüá≥ SAP Build: Advanced Event Mesh - Event based SAP Build Process Automation (Bengaluru, India)
entry.content:
This is the all-new SAP CodeJam for SAP Build low-code/no-code tooling that focuses on giving you hands-on experience for building event-triggered processes with SAP Build Process Automation.

You will build an event-based scenario that lets users create S/4HANA business partners, setting off a process where:
  1. An employee approves the creation of a site access badge.
  2. A second employee, determined based on the details of the business partner, may also need to approve the badge.
  3. The process calls an external, 3rd-party badge system and waits to be called back.
  4. A user creates the badge and the badge system calls back the process instance.
  5. A notification with the badge ID is sent.

 

The scenario is built in 2 halves:
 
SAP Integration Suite, advanced event mesh: You will learn about events, CloudEvents, events in the SAP landscape, the process for publishing and subscribing to events, and your way around SAP Integration Suite, advanced event mesh. Then, you will create a REST Delivery Point in advanced event mesh to forward events to your SAP Build on your SAP BTP trial account.
 
SAP Build Process Automation: You will create a process from scratch to handle the issuance of site access badges. You will learn the basics of SAP Build Process Automation (projects, triggers, conditions, creating instances, monitoring, and the Inbox), and also use some of the more recent or advanced features (event triggers, form events, waiting for a API callback).
 
Prerequisites
  • Bring your own laptop with power adapter and have a supported Web browser such as Google Chrome or Firefox installed on your laptop.
  • It can be helpful to bring a tablet or second laptop, if you have.
  • Complete these prerequisites and the required reading BEFORE you come: 
    • Introduction to the CodeJam
    • Prerequisites
    • Required reading:
      • 1 - Exploring Events and More in the SAP Business Accelerator Hub
      • 2 - Why Event-Driven Architectures?

Location and Date

This is an in-person event only (not virtual) and is planned for Thursday, January 29th, 2026 from 9:30 - 16:00 local time in Bengaluru, India. The language of the event and the content will be English. 

Event Address:  Ericsson Global, AQUAMARINE WTC 03 and CITRINE WTC 04, Bagmane World Technology Centre, SEZ, Outer Ring Road, Bengaluru, Bengaluru Urban, Karnataka, 560048

Google maps location: https://maps.app.goo.gl/xJHoXAdLbEHKR9CHA 

  • The instructors are SAP Developer Advocates  @ajay_soreng  and @Rekha_DR 
  • Thank you Ericsson Global for hosting this event.

Please note that spaces are limited! We can only accommodate 30 attendees. If you want to attend, register by clicking the Yes button in the Will you be attending? section above to the right. About two weeks before the event, you will be asked to confirm your attendance via email.

entry.title: Re: SAP Intercompany Processes: STO with Billing step by step guideline
entry.content:
Hi Harsh_Joshi,

In an intercompany STO scenario, the billing document is indeed created first by the supplying company after goods issue. This intercompany billing document is then sent to the receiving company, and invoice verification (MIRO) is carried out with reference to this billing document, not directly against the delivery.

So the sequence is:
Goods Issue --> Intercompany Billing --> Invoice Verification in receiving company.

Hope this clarifies your doubt.

Regards,

Leelamohan

entry.title: Re: Making SAP Business One Web Client accessible externally using nginx as a reverse proxy
entry.content:
Hi @Andre_S 
Thanks for your comment.
You are right, within current B1 Architecture, components have dependency on SLD and Authentication service at runtime for landscape discovery, user authentication and tenant/DB resolution.
As a result both SLD and Authentication service need to be accessible. By using  the Nginx template you can minimize exposure to a single URL and Port for both.
Any deviation from this setup would require a deep ARC change I'm affraid.
Feel free to share your idea for potential future improvements and get community's vote on it via Customer influence https://influence.sap.com/sap/ino/#/campaign/887 

Best Regards
Guy

entry.title: Cleaning Zero and Blank Base Cost Records in SAP Analytics Cloud BW Live for Clear Variance Trends
entry.content:
Business Background

In BW Live‚Äìbased cost analysis, variance trends are often affected by records that contain zero or blank Base Cost values.
These records usually belong to:

  • Old projects
  • Pass-through orders
  • Closure or migrated projects

Including them in trend analysis makes charts noisy and less meaningful for management discussions.

 

What the Execute Button Does

When the user clicks the Execute button:

  • WBS TOPs with zero or blank Base Cost values are removed
  • The remaining records are used to calculate:
    • Approximate cumulative variance
    • Year-wise variance trend
  • The chart becomes easier to read and interpret

At the same time, the story still provides:

  • One table and chart with all records
  • One table and chart without zero or blank records

This gives full transparency to the user.

 

Important Business Clarification

Removing these WBS TOPs does not impact the actual variance calculation in a material way.

Reason:

  • Zero or blank Base Cost values appear mainly in Main projects
  • These projects are mostly old or pass-through in nature
  • Proper Base Cost and Actuals are correctly tracked in Sub- projects

So the filtered view improves visual clarity, not financial accuracy.

 

Design Approach in SAP Analytics Cloud

The solution uses a helper table‚Äìbased dynamic filtering pattern.

High-level logic:

  1. Read data from a helper table
  2. Identify WBS TOPs with non-zero Base Cost
  3. Collect only valid WBS TOP IDs
  4. Apply the filter dynamically to:
    • Main chart
    • Main table
  5. Remove the filter automatically if no valid records exist

This logic runs only when the user clicks Execute, keeping the story fast.

 

Simplified SAC Script

// Source helper table

var dsSource = Table_Helper.getDataSource();

 

// Target chart and table

var dsTargetChart = Chart_Main.getDataSource();

var dsTargetTable = Table_Main.getDataSource();

 

// Read result set

var rs = dsSource.getResultSet();

var validWbsList = ArrayUtils.create(Type.string);

 

// Collect WBS TOPs with non-zero and non-blank Base Cost

for (var i = 0; i < rs.length; i++) {

    var wbs = rs[i]["DIM_WBS_TOP"];

    var measure = rs[i]["@MeasureDimension"];

 

    if (measure && measure.formattedValue !== "0" && measure.formattedValue !== "") {

        validWbsList.push(wbs.id);

    }

}

 

// Apply or remove filters

if (validWbsList.length > 0) {

    dsTargetChart.setDimensionFilter("DIM_WBS_TOP", validWbsList);

    dsTargetTable.setDimensionFilter("DIM_WBS_TOP", validWbsList);

} else {

    dsTargetChart.removeDimensionFilter("DIM_WBS_TOP");

    dsTargetTable.removeDimensionFilter("DIM_WBS_TOP");

}

 

Why This Pattern Works Well

Technical Benefits

  • Fully compatible with BW Live
  • No hard-coded filters
  • Clean and reusable scripting
  • No impact on backend data

Business Benefits

  • Clear variance trends
  • Better year-wise comparison
  • Transparent view for auditors and controllers
  • Faster management discussions

 

Conclusion

Using an Execute button to remove WBS TOPs with zero or blank Base Cost values is a simple yet powerful way to improve variance trend analysis in SAP Analytics Cloud. By combining helper tables and dynamic dimension filtering, you get better insights without compromising data integrity.

entry.title: Re: A New Paradigm for Enterprise AI: In-Context Learning for Relational Data
entry.content:
Hello @pkovac, 

SAP-RPT-1 is now generally available on SAP generative AI hub in 2 model versions - SAP-RPT-1-small and SAP-RPT-1-large - under both sap-internal or extended plans. Similar to the LLMs, the model versions will be available in the Model Library within generative AI hub. You can use SAP AI Launchpad to navigate AI Core functionalities.

Do read our latest blog post, where we explained the model versions in detail. We will also be releasing a second blog post shortly which contains a step-by-step guide on how to get started with SAP-RPT-1.

entry.title: Electronic Signatures Made Simpler with Docusign Adapter in SAP Integration Suite
entry.content:
Introduction

Signatures are part of almost every transaction in the world. However, nowadays most documents are sent by email, and asking someone to sign them physically feels pretty old-school, isn‚Äôt it?

This is  why electronic signatures are becoming more relevant by the day.

DocuSign is an ideal tool to help you send contracts that require electronic signatures. It provides a secure method which is legally valid for obtaining electronic signatures.

Docusign Adapter in SAP Cloud Integration

The Docusign adapter is designed to function as a receiver adapter. It connects SAP Integration Suite to Docusign and enables you to manage and configure Docusign objects to integrate features like embedded sending, e-signatures, etc into your applications.

It offers the following features:

  • Allows you to perform several operations such as Create, Read, Update, and Delete (CRUD) for entities such as Envelopes, SigningGroups and Template etc.
  • Allows secure authentication via OAuth 2.0 and JSON Web Token based authentication.
  • Supports Basic configuration for convenient processing capability whereas Advanced enables proficient users to perform calls with greater control while connecting to any API endpoint.
  • Allows flexibility while retrieving metadata using Query Parameter field.
  • Supports response output formats like JSON, XML.

In this blog post, we will deep dive into Create Envelope operation. By the end of this blog, you will be able to learn enough to use it. So, let‚Äôs get started!

Use Case Description

Let us consider a scenario where the employer wants to send an employment contract in a PDF format to a new employee joining their organization. The document can contain terms of employment and if the employee agrees, they can sign it with an electronic signature. Simple enough, isn‚Äôt it?

Let us look at a high-level diagram to understand this further.

Source system can be SAP SuccessFactors, SAP S4HANA or any other system capable of sending the PDF document to SAP Cloud Integration. Note that the document type can also be .docx. However, to retain formatting of document .pdf file is considered.

For our use case, we will consider an example of Microsoft Sharepoint as a source system where an employment contract is placed. Microsoft Sharepoint sender adapter in SAPCI will pick this contract from respective directory or folder. Contract documents will be sent in an envelope format to Docusign using Docusign adapter. Docusign will send this envelope to signer via email.

I hope by now you have got an idea how the overall process is going to work, right?

For detailed explanation, refer to the section Creating an integration flow in SAP Cloud Integration later in this blog post. Let us now understand the prerequisites to get this scenario working.

Pre-requisites

Make sure that you have:

1. Access to Microsoft sharepoint to place PDF document (Sample employment contract).

Refer to the SAP blog by @siddhartha_routh who has nicely explained in detail how to setup connectivity with Microsoft Sharepoint.

https://community.sap.com/t5/technology-blog-posts-by-members/integrating-sap-btp-cpi-with-microsoft-sharepoint-part-1-establishing/ba-p/13924728.

Note down the details like Client ID, Client Secret, Authorization URL, Token Service URL etc. which will be used to connect Microsoft Sharepoint from SAP Cloud Integration.

2. Access to SAP Cloud Integration to create artifacts and security materials.

3. Access to Docusign (Free trial developer account should also be fine). Please follow this step-by-step guide to get started with Docusign: https://developers.docusign.com/platform/build-integration/

3.1.1. Login to Developer Account > Go to Admin Dashboard > INTEGRATIONS > Apps and Keys > Add App and Integration Key https://apps-d.docusign.com/admin/apps-and-keys

Account Base URI in above screenshot is the address to connect with Docusign. This is used in Connection tab in Docusign adapter in SAP Cloud Integration. API Account ID is used in the Processing tab in Docusign adapter in SAP Cloud Integration.

3.1.2. Create an App with name SAPCI. Integration Key will be auto generated. This is going to be the Client ID in OAuth2 Authorization Code credentials in SAP CI.

3.1.3. Select an authentication method for your app. Refer to the below link for various authentication methods available to connect with Docusign https://developers.docusign.com/platform/auth/ .

We have used Authorization Code Grant. For more information, see https://developers.docusign.com/platform/auth/confidential-authcode-get-token/ for more details.

Click on Add Secret Key button. Remember to note down this secret key as soon as it is generated. This is going to be the Client Secret in OAuth2 Authorization Code credentials in SAP CI.

3.1.4. In SAP Cloud Integration > Go to Monitor > Manage Security > Security Material > Create > OAuth2 Authorization Code.

For the developer environment:

Authorization URL is https://account-d.docusign.com/oauth/auth .

Token Service URL is https://account-d.docusign.com/oauth/token

Provide Client ID (Integration Key from Step 3.1.2) and Client Secret (Secret Key from step 3.1.3)

For this use case, we have defined the scope signature which enables an app to call the eSignature REST API. Note down the Redirect URL from the credential section which will be used to be configure in the SAPCI app created in DocuSign.

3.1.5. Under Additional Settings > Add Redirect URIs. Copy and paste the Redirect URL obtained in the previous step, Allowed HTTP methods you might use and click Save.

3.1.6. Go back to OAuth2 Authorization Code credentials again and click Authorize. The status by default is Unauthorized.

3.1.7. You will be redirected to a new webpage for consent. Click Allow Access.

You should receive a success message like below which confirms that the refresh token has been added into credential.

3.1.8. Close and refresh the Manage Security Material screen, you should now see the status as Deployed. You can use this credential to establish connection with Docusign.

 

Creating an integration flow in SAP Cloud Integration

Steps

  1. Microsoft Sharepoint Sender Adapter in SAP Cloud Integration polls files from Sharepoint directory as per scheduled frequency.

Connection: Provide the details of Sharepoint server like site host name, server relative path, authentication type etc.

You can choose either OAuth2 Authorization Code or OAuth2 Client Credentials as an authentication type. I have selected OAuth2 Client Credentials.

In SAP Cloud Integration > Go to Monitor > Manage Security > Security Material > Create > OAuth2 Client Credentials. Provide Token Service URL, Client ID, Client Secret obtained from Pre-requisites explained earlier in this blog. Set scope as https://graph.microsoft.com/.default.

Once all the details are provided, deploy credentials.

Processing: Provide the processing parameters for the file like Directory, File Name, Post-processing etc.

Scheduler: You can schedule an integration flow to poll files from Sharepoint.

2. Base64 Encoder will encode the PDF document in Base64 format to safely transfer binary data through systems. This also ensures the file's integrity and prevent corruption during transmission.

3. Content Modifier is used to prepare DocuSign API Payload (in our case Create Envelope data) in JSON format. The details provided in this step are used while sending an email from DocuSign in Step 5. Without JSON payload, DocuSign would receive a PDF document with no context, no recipient information, and no instructions on where to place the signature fields, making the transaction impossible to process. That‚Äôs why JSON payload is necessary.

Message Body

Type: Expression

JSON Body: 

{
  "emailSubject": "Please Sign: Sample Employment Contract Letter for DocuSign Use Case",
  "status": "sent",
  "documents": [
    {
      "documentId": "1",
      "name": "Sample Employment Contract Letter for DocuSign Use Case.pdf",
      "fileExtension": "pdf",
      "documentBase64": "${body}"
    }
  ],
  "recipients": {
    "signers": [
      {
        "email": "<Enter email ID of recipient here>",
        "name": "<Enter name of recipient here>",
        "recipientId": "1",
        "routingOrder": "1",
        "tabs": {
          "signHereTabs": [
            {
              // --- This defines where the signature goes ---
              "anchorString": "/signature/",
              "anchorXOffset": "10",
              "anchorYOffset": "10",
              "anchorIgnoreIfNotPresent": "false",
              "documentId": "1",
              "pageNumber": "1" // This can be ignored if anchor string is reliable
            }
          ]
        }
      }
    ]
  }
}

More Information about Key Payload Components

  • Including the PDF Content as Base64: The DocuSign API doesn't accept a raw file upload in this combined request structure. It requires the document content to be converted into a Base64 encoded string within the documentBase64 field.
  • Defining the Recipient and signHere tab : The recipients object is where you define who needs to sign and what they need to sign. signHereTabs array: This is a crucial nested object. It tells DocuSign to place a standard signature box.
  • Using anchorString for AutoPlace: The most elegant and robust way to place the signature field is the anchorString parameter within the signHereTabs object.

"anchorString": "/signature/": DocuSign scans the PDF document for this exact string.

"anchorIgnoreIfNotPresent": "false": This is useful for development. If set to true, the envelope will still send even if the string is missing. If set to false, the API call will fail with an error, alerting you that your PDF template is misconfigured.

  • Fine-Tuning with Offsets: You need to adjust where the signature block appears relative to your anchor text.

"anchorYOffset": "10" (or "-10"): Moves the signature field vertically (up or down) from the baseline of your anchor text. A positive number moves it down.

"anchorXOffset": "0" (or "50"): Moves the signature field horizontally (left or right).

"documentId": "1": Links this specific signature tab to the document you included in the documents array that has documentId set to "1".

4. Using request-reply, send a Create Envelope request to DocuSign and get Envelope ID on a successful response.

The connection tab uses following parameters:

Parameter

Description

Address

Specify the address of Docusign to be used for the connection.

Example: https://account.docusign.com

Authentication

Specify the address of Docusign to be used for the connection:

¬∑        JSON Web Token (JWT)

¬∑        OAuth 2.0 Authorization Code

Authentication Base URL

Specify the name of the Secure Parameter artifact that contains the User ID needed to connect to Docusign.

Client ID Alias

Specify the Secure Parameter artifact that contains the Client ID needed to connect to Docusign.

User ID Alias

Specify the Secure Parameter artifact that contains the User ID needed to connect to Docusign.

RSA Key Alias

Specify the RSA key alias for connecting to the Docusign account.

Authorization Code Credentials

(Only available when OAuth 2.0 Authorization Code is selected)

Specify the Secure Parameter key alias that stores the Docusign OAuth Authorization Code.

Reuse Connection

Enable to reuse the connection. This option enables the reuse of connection objects from the internal connection pool which in turn improves the network turnaround time for multiple communications to a same end point.

Connection Timeout (in ms)

Specify the maximum waiting time (in milliseconds) for the connection to be established.

Example: 6000

Response Timeout (in ms)

Specify the maximum waiting time (in milliseconds) for a response message.

Example: 60000

The Processing tab contains all operation related configurations for the Docusign Receiver adapter.

Parameter

Description

Configuration Type

Select the required configuration type:

¬∑        Basic to use the dropdowns and parameter text fields.

¬∑        Advanced to specify the relative URL.

Entity

Specify the entity on which the operation is to be performed.

Operation

Select the operation to be performed.

File Name

Specify the file name of the resource being uploaded.

Query Parameter

Specify the expression containing the query parameter and value.

Example:include_external_references,include_logos

Count

Specify the maximum number of results to return.

Acceptable values range from 1 to 100.

Start Position

Specify the zero-based index of the result from which to start returning results.

Resource Parameters

Specify the Name and Value in case the resource path includes parameters.

Example: Set Name to propertyKey & Value to 76548.

Request

Select the format for request payload.

Response

Select the format for response payload.

Request Headers

Enter a list of custom headers, separated by a pipe (|), to send to the target system. By default, no custom headers are sent. Use an asterisk (*) to send all custom headers to the target system. Alternatively, you can dynamically pass on the values by defining a property that includes a list of headers.

Response Headers

Enter a list of headers coming from the target system's response, separated by a pipe (|), to be received in the message. Use an asterisk (*) to receive all the headers from the target system, which is also the default value.

5. DocuSign internally takes care of sending an email to recipient/s retrieved from Step#3. Signer can review and electronically sign the document. Once done, a completion email will be sent to signer from Docusign.

Let‚Äôs run our integration

Steps

  1. Take a Sample Employment Contract Letter like below. You can just copy-paste this content into WORD document. 
Employment Contract Letter
Dear [Employee Name],
We are pleased to offer you the position of [Job Title] at [Company Name]. This letter outlines the terms and conditions of your employment.
1. Position and Responsibilities
You will be employed as [Job Title], reporting to [Reporting Manager/Department]. You are expected to perform the duties and responsibilities assigned to you in a professional and efficient manner.
2. Compensation
Your compensation package will include:
‚Ä¢	Salary: [Salary Details ‚Äì optional to state]
‚Ä¢	Benefits: As per company policy, including any applicable medical, insurance, or other benefits.
3. Work Location
Your designated place of work will be [Office Location / Remote Arrangement].
4. Company Policies
You agree to follow all company rules, regulations, and policies as communicated through the employee handbook or official HR communications.
5. Employment Classification
Your employment with the company is classified as [Full-Time / Part-Time / Contractual / Probationary].
6. Confidentiality & Conduct
During your employment, you are expected to maintain confidentiality of all company information and adhere to professional standards of conduct.
7. Acceptance of Offer
By signing below, you confirm that you have read, understood, and agree to the terms and conditions of your employment with [Company Name].
We look forward to welcoming you to our team.
Sincerely,
[HR Representative Name]
[HR Title/Designation]
[Company Name]
________________________________________
Employee Acceptance
I accept the terms of employment as stated above.

Employee Signature:  /signature/

 Make sure that the anchorString is present in the document where Docusign will place the Signature box.

To hide achorString from the document, you can simply change the font colour of text to white. This way, the anchor string would be still there in document but not visible to the signer.

Once your document is ready, convert it into PDF format using any online tool. See below to visualize how your PDF may look like.

 2. Place the letter on sharepoint directory to pick by an Integration flow

3. The integration flow runs successfully and returns Envelope ID from Docusign. File is moved to archive directory as per post-processing configuration.

4. Email is sent on recipient‚Äôs email ID to review and sign. Click Review Document.

5. Document will open and observe the Sign box appears exactly where the anchorString was present.

6. Review the document and click on Sign button. Select, draw or upload the signature you wish to use for signing the document. Once done, click on Adopt and Sign. Signature appears, click on Finish.

7. You can see a confirmation message like the one below. Signer also receives an email with completion of the document.

8. If you click on View Completed Document, you can see the signed document. The same is also attached in the email.

9. Additionally, you can also see the completed agreements in Docusign directly on home page https://apps-d.docusign.com/send/home under Agreement activity. See below screenshot

Key Learnings and Takeaways

In this blog, we explored how Docusign adapter in SAP cloud integration can help to implement a simple yet practical use case which makes implementation of electronic signatures effective and super easy. This isn‚Äôt all that you can do with Docusign adapter, take a look at all operations supported by adapter and try them out yourself.

References

https://help.sap.com/docs/integration-suite/sap-integration-suite/docusign-adapter

Note: The Docusign adapter is also available as a part of your SAP Integration Suite license.

I hope this blog helps you think broadly about how the Docusign adapter can fit into your integration scenarios to deliver value to your customers.

Thank you for reading all the way through. Keep sharing and Keep learning üòä!!

Regards,

Vishal Ingale

entry.title: Status Report Configuration and Template Usage in SAP PPM
entry.content:
Hello SAP Experts,

I have some doubts regarding Status Reports in SAP PPM ‚Äì Project Management and would like clarification on the following points.

 

Question 1: Status Report Creation Options

There are two configuration options available for creating Status Reports:

  1. If the Status Report checkbox is selected under Activate Status Reports, Status Report can be created for the project.
  2. If ‚ÄúCheck in Status Reports in SAP DMS‚Äù is checked under Activate Status Reports.

Could someone please explain:

  • The purpose of these two options
  • In which scenarios both options need to be selected, or when only the Status Report checkbox is sufficient

 

Question 2: Purpose of Storing Status Reports

What is the purpose of storing Status Reports in:

  • Project Management (PPM)
  • SAP Document Management System (DMS)

In which scenarios should Status Reports be stored only in Project Management, and when is it recommended to store them in SAP DMS?

 

Question 3: Usage of Standard Status Report Objects and Checkbox Restrictions

I see multiple standard DPR objects available, such as:

  • DPR_APPROVAL_HIER
  • DPR_CHECKLIST_HIER
  • DPR_CHECKLIST_ITEM_HIER
  • DPR_NOTES
  • DPR_PHASE_HIER
  • DPR_PROJECT_HIER
  • DPR_STATUS_REPORT_AIF
  • DPR_TASK_HIER

I would like to know how to use all the report templates while creating a status report.

However, according to SAP Help Portal documentation, when using DPR_STATUS_REPORT_STATIC or DPR_STATUS_REPORT_AIF, only the Active and Status Rpt checkboxes must be selected, and the remaining checkboxes under Status Rpt must not be selected.

This creates confusion because:

  • Multiple standard Status Report‚Äìrelated DPR objects exist
  • The system restricts enabling the remaining Status Rpt checkboxes
  • When attempting to select them, the system throws an error stating that the option ‚Äúcannot be checked‚Äù

Could someone please clarify:

  • Why the remaining Status Rpt checkboxes must not be selected when using DPR_STATUS_REPORT_STATIC or DPR_STATUS_REPORT_AIF
  • How the other standard DPR objects (approval, checklist, notes, task, phase, etc.) are used if their corresponding checkboxes are not enabled
    Your inputs and explanations on this topic would be highly appreciated
    Thank you in advance.

entry.title: How to display text within mult-input field?
entry.content:
I've created a multi-input field with value help. But I was not able to display the text instead of key in my multi-input field.
https://sapui5.hana.ondemand.com/sdk/#/topic/04ff5b1a81344a8e8169ea99630ff4e5 

 

I've annotated my field like this:

 

@ui: {
lineItem: [ {
position: 90,
value: '_ZPayrollArea.HCMPayrollArea',
label: 'Payroll Areas',
importance: #HIGH } ],
textArrangement: #TEXT_FIRST
}
_ZPayrollArea;


And the Interface view is linked like this:

--Payroll Area as Detail data
composition [0..*] of Z_I_ZFCompany_PayrllArea_S as _ZPayrollArea

The projection view:

_ZPayrollArea : redirected to composition child Z_C_ZPayrllArea_S,

The projection view detail:

define view entity Z_C_ZPayrllArea_S
--Projection of Interface View Payrolls
as projection on Z_I_ZPayrllArea_S
{
....
--Payroll Area
@Consumption.valueHelpDefinition: [{ entity : { name: 'Z_I_PayrollArea_VH',
element: 'HCMPayrollArea' } }]
key HCMPayrollArea,
--Payroll Area Name
@Semantics.text: true
@search.defaultSearchElement: true
_HCMPayrollArea._Text.HCMPayrollAreaName : localized,
...
/* Associations */
_Root : redirected to parent Z_C_ZRoot_S,
...}

value help:

@Consumption.valueHelpDefault.fetchValues: #AUTOMATICALLY_WHEN_DISPLAYED
define view entity Z_I_PayrollArea_VH
--Select from Payroll Area
as select from I_HCMPayrollArea
{
--Payroll
@search.defaultSearchElement: true
@search.ranking: #HIGH
@search.fuzzinessThreshold: 0.75
@ObjectModel.text.element: [ 'HCMPayrollAreaName' ]
@ui.textArrangement: #TEXT_FIRST
key HCMPayrollArea,
--Payroll Description
@ui.hidden: true
_Text[ 1: Language = $session.system_language ].HCMPayrollAreaName as HCMPayrollAreaName
}

If I try to annotate "@ObjectModel.text.element: [ 'HCMPayrollAreaName' ]" the value help is no longer dispalyed, but the text. And without the annotation, the value help works fine.

How can I display the value help and the text (as textarrangement #TEXT_FIRST)?

entry.title: Re: SAP Public Cloud- data volume / enterprise Project WBS
entry.content:
Good day @Malorie 

Thank you for your question

Regarding your question on volumes of project master data, the Migration Cockpit within the public cloud can surely handle large volumes of project data. For example, over 100,000 WBS elements are technically supported but as you are aware, performance of data migration vary based on various factors (e.g., complexity of your project structures, your system load, staging area capacity, etc.). Therefore, I recommend you:

  • Split your data into packages during upload
  • Consider using staging approach instead of uploading large volume of files.
  • Ensure your project definition is available before dependent WBS elements
  • Ensur you pre-validate your source data to and ensure your data relationships are intact.

 

Here are some references that provide good insights: https://help.sap.com/docs/SAP_S4HANA_CLOUD/d5699934e7004d048c4801b552f3b013/12a09cef557b4e09a446ae4d883e46eb.html?locale=en-US

https://help.sap.com/doc/69dd0f1ef0034261ab6e617e0b2beb21/2021.latest/en-US/MigrationObjects_OP_EN.pdf?forSiteMap=true

For your finance closing activities, based on my experience, I would suggest:

  1. For settlement performance:
    • make sure you scale with number of WBS elements and volume of your actuals,
    • when you use public cloud, ensure you avoid running settlements during peak hours.
    • Optimising your CO configurations and number of ranges are essential.
  2. For your Overhead calculation:
    • Note that, if you activate it, that might cause runtime issues if costs are too detailed.
    • Therefore, consider simplifying your costing structures.
  3. For your G/L Integration:
    • One big challenge I am aware of is the correct assignment of the WBS element types to the right G/L accounts. If this is not done correctly, it might block postings or lead to misclassification.

In summary, my general recommendation for your project migration is to make use of Job templates during low-traffic times, make use of the Monitor Application Jobs app to track and troubleshoot and make sure you check your CBC settings for project control parameters (e.g., number of levels allowed).

You may consider using Custom Analytical Queries or CDS Views with filters when you work with large data.

 

Best regards

Chris

entry.title: SAP Signavio: Available Process Diagrams and their Niche Use
entry.content:
SAP Signavio provides several standard process diagram types, each tailored for a different purpose in process modelling, analysis, and optimization. Below is a clear list of the most common diagram types you will encounter in SAP Signavio Process Manager and Journey Modeler, along with what they are used for.

 1. BPMN 2.0 Process Diagram (Business Process Model and Notation)

 

This is the primary and most widely used diagram type in SAP Signavio.

BPMN (Business Process Model and Notation) diagrams are used to visually represent business processes in a standardized, easy-to-understand way. They allow both business users and technical teams to understand how a process works end-to-end.

  • Modelling end-to-end business processes
  • Executable workflows
  • Standardized communication between business and IT

Includes elements like:
Events, tasks, gateways, pools/lanes, data objects, subprocesses, message flows.

1. Documenting Business Processes

BPMN diagrams help organizations clearly document how work is done.

Examples:

  • Order-to-Cash
  • Procure-to-Pay
  • Hire-to-Retire
  • Customer support escalation

2. Process Analysis & Improvement

Teams use BPMN diagrams to identify:

  • Bottlenecks
  • Redundant tasks
  • Delays
  • Opportunities for automation

3. Fit-to-Standard Workshops (SAP Projects)

In SAP implementations (like S/4HANA), BPMN diagrams are used to:

  • Compare current processes vs SAP Best Practices
  • Capture gaps (‚Üí Cloud ALM requirements)
  • Align business teams around a unified process

4. Workflow and Automation Design

BPMN is the standard notation for designing automation flows used in:

  • SAP Build Process Automation
  • SAP Signavio Workflow Accelerator
  • RPA bots
  • Integration flows

The model becomes the blueprint for technical implementation.

5. Training and Communication

Because BPMN is visual and standardized, it is used for:

  • End-user training
  • SOP documentation
  • Cross-team communication

6. System Integration & Monitoring (Cloud ALM)

In SAP Cloud ALM, BPMN diagrams help map:

  • Business process steps ‚Üí monitoring events
  • Interfaces ‚Üí message flows
  • Exception handling paths

This allows process-centric monitoring.

2. EPC (Event-Driven Process Chain)

Used mostly by organizations from SAP Solution Manager / ARIS backgrounds.

Used for:

  • High-level process documentation
  • SAP S/4HANA transformation projects
  • Linking events ‚Üí functions ‚Üí rules
    1. High-Level Process Documentation (Level 1‚Äì2 Processes)

    In Signavio, EPCs are often used to represent high-level, conceptual business processes before going into detailed BPMN modeling.

    Why:

    • Easier for executives and business users
    • Shows process logic without technical detail
    • Good for workshops and business alignment
    1. Documenting AS-IS Processes for SAP Transformations

    Many organizations migrating to S/4HANA use EPCs to document current-state processes, especially if they previously used:

    • SAP Solution Manager
    • ARIS
    • SAP Blueprint methodology

    Why EPC here:

    • Mirrors older SAP documentation formats
    • Simpler representation than BPMN
    • Faster to model at a high level
    1. Building End-to-End Process Landscape / Architecture

    EPCs work very well for process landscape mapping, such as:

    • Level 0 Value Chain
    • Level 1 Core Processes (O2C, P2P, H2R)
    • Level 2 Subprocesses

    In Signavio, many customers model their entire enterprise process hierarchy using EPCs.

    1. Pre-BPMN Modelling for Detailed Design

    Many Signavio users follow a two-step modelling approach:

    Step 1 ‚Üí EPC:
    Capture conceptual flow (events + functions)

    Step 2 ‚Üí BPMN:
    Convert detailed flows into executable workflows

    This avoids making BPMN diagrams overly complex.

    5. Fit-to-Standard Workshops (High-Level View)

    During SAP Fit-to-Standard discussions, EPCs can be used to:

    • Introduce the process at a business-friendly level
    • Compare AS-IS to SAP Best Practice TO-BE
    • Identify gaps before creating Cloud ALM requirements
      6. Represent Processes Without Technical Details

    EPC is preferred when:

    • No need to show message flows
    • No need to model system integrations
    • The process is non-automated or conceptual
    • Only business decision flow matters

    This makes EPC the simpler choice compared to BPMN.

    Why Organizations Use EPCs in Signavio Even Today

    Reason

    Explanation

    ‚úî Business-friendly visuals

    Functions + events are simple to read

    ‚úî Legacy familiarity

    Many SAP customers used EPC for 10+ years

    ‚úî Good for high-level processes

    Ideal before jumping into BPMN

    ‚úî Works well with process landscapes

    Great for level 0‚Äì2 diagrams

    ‚úî Not as technical as BPMN

    Suitable for non-IT stakeholders

    EPC vs BPMN in Signavio ‚Äî When to Use Which

    Use Case

    Recommended

    High-level process overview

    EPC

    Conceptual business flow

    EPC

    SAP AS-IS documentation

    EPC

    End-to-end process landscape

    EPC

    Detailed flow (roles, systems)

    BPMN

    Workflow automation

    BPMN

    Detailed technical integration

    BPMN

     Example EPC Diagram (Signavio Style)

     

     

3. SIPOC Diagram (Supplier ‚Äì Input ‚Äì Process ‚Äì Output ‚Äì Customer)

 

 

 

Used for:

  • Lean Six Sigma
  • Defining high-level process boundaries
  • Mapping suppliers, inputs, outputs, customers

4. Journey Models (Customer / Employee Journeys)

 

Used for:

  • Mapping customer or employee experiences
  • Identifying pain points and opportunities
  • Aligning processes with customer expectations

6. DMN Decision Model (Decision Model & Notation)

 

Used for:

  • Business rules modelling
  • Decision tables
  • Automation and rule evaluation

Often linked to BPMN processes for decision logic.

7. Organization Charts (Org Chart)

 

Used for:

  • Mapping roles, departments, reporting lines
  • Connecting organizational units to processes

8. Diagram for Process Data / Dictionary Models

(Not a visual diagram like BPMN‚Äîmore of a structured data model)

Used for:

  • Maintaining global process documentation assets
  • Centralizing terms, IT systems, roles, KPIs

Summary Table

Diagram Type

Purpose

BPMN 2.0

Detailed end-to-end process modeling

EPC

High-level SAP process documentation

SIPOC

Quick scoping and boundary definition

Value Chain / Hierarchy

Process architecture and taxonomy

Journey Models

Customer/employee experience mapping

DMN Decision Models

Business rules & logic

Org Charts

Organizational structure mapping

Dictionary Models

Central documentation repository

How BPMNs Connect with SAP CloudALM implementation and Operations (Chapter 2)

Using Signavio in S4/Hana Conversion along with SAP Activate methodology(Chapter 3)

entry.title: How to Fetch Custom Fields in FI Customer Invoice Adobe Form S/4HANA Public Cloud
entry.content:
Hello Experts,

I am currently working on an SAP S/4HANA Public Cloud Implementation and Involved in Custom Adobe Form Development using Adobe Lifecycle Designer for the FI Customer Invoice (Credit Note & Debit Note).              The Form is Triggered via Manage Journal Entries : Create Correspondence.

We have successfully mapped all Standard Fields using the standard Data Source. However, we now have a requirement to map additional Custom Fields in the Form.

Currently, standard fields are mapped using the standard Data Source. however, there is a requirement to fetch and Display additional Custom Fields in the Adobe Form. To achieve this, we explored enhancement options using Custom Logic BADIs and identified the Business Context FIN_ACDOC_ITEM_SUBSTITUTION. However, this BADI is triggered before Document posting, at which point the Accounting Document Number is not yet available. As a result, it is not possible to perform a SELECT query on the custom CDS view or related tables to retrieve the required custom field values. Furthermore, no suitable BADI or Business Context triggered after posting has been identified to support form enhancement for this scenario.

The current requirement is to identify a supported enhancement solution in S/4HANA Public Cloud to enhance the FI Customer Invoice Adobe Form by fetching and mapping custom fields, preferably using a post posting BADI or any other supported enhancement option.

Additional Information Provided :-

Application Name :- Manage Journal Entries                                                                                                                        Form :- SAP 21 FI Customer Invoice                                                                                                                                        Application Object ID :- Accounting Document (FI_ACCDOC)                                                                                          Output Type :- Invoice (INVOICE)                                                                                                                                                  Channel :- Print                                                                                                                                                                        Business Context for Custom Field :- Accounting : Journal Entry Item                                                                                  Data Source :- FDP_FFO_FI_INVOICE_SRV                                                                                                                                  Standard Form Template :- FIN_FO_CORR_FICUS_INV_E

Is there any supported BADI or Business Context in S/4HANA Public Cloud to enhance a custom Adobe Form after posting or else Alternatively, is there a supported way to fetch custom fields using CDS extensions, form enhancements, or output parameter mapping ?

 

Thank you,
Yash Rudraksha,

entry.title: SAP S/4HANA Public Cloud ‚Äì Dunning Notice Email to Customer + Multiple Contact Persons from BP
entry.content:
Hi SAP Community,

We are using SAP S/4HANA Public Cloud (3SL) and are trying to configure Dunning Notice emails so that email IDs are picked dynamically from BP master data, without hardcoding email addresses.

Requirement

When a dunning run is executed:

Email should be sent to the Customer BP email

Email should also be sent to all linked Contact Persons‚Äô email IDs

Multiple Contact Persons should receive the email automatically

All email IDs must be derived only from BP master (Customer + Contact Person)

What we have already configured

  1. BP Master

Customer BP has email maintained in Address ‚Üí Communication

Contact Person BPs have email maintained

Relationships maintained: Has Contact Person, Has Dunning Recipient

  1. Output Parameter Determination ‚Äì Receiver

Application: Dunning

Determination Step: Receiver

Decision Table: DT_RECEIVER

Entry maintained:

Output Type = DUNN_NOTICE

Account Type = D (Customer) Role = D Exclusive Indicator = false

Note: We do not see CP (Contact Person) as a selectable Role in Receiver.

  1. Output Parameter Determination ‚Äì Email Recipient

Determination Step: Email Recipient

Decision Table: DT_EMAIL_RECEIVER

Entries maintained:

Row 1: Output Type = DUNN_NOTICE,  Email Type = TO, Email Address = Context ‚Üí Customer ‚Üí Email Address

Row 2: Output Type = DUNN_NOTICE, Email Type = TO Email Address = Context ‚Üí Contact Person ‚Üí Email Address

 

Issue / Clarification Required

CP (Contact Person) does not appear as a Role in Receiver determination

It is unclear whether Contact Persons are implicitly derived during Email Recipient determination

Despite maintaining BP relationships and Email Recipient context mapping, the behavior is not clearly documented

Questions

  1. In SAP S/4HANA Public Cloud, is it standard behavior that Contact Persons are not selectable in the Receiver Role?
  2. Is the above configuration sufficient for sending dunning emails to:
    1. Customer BP email, and
    2. All Contact Person emails marked as Dunning Recipient?
  3. Is there any additional configuration or prerequisite required for Contact Person email determination?
  4. Is there any SAP documentation or note confirming this behavior?

entry.title: Re: Fiori APP, F2689, Record Results for Inspection Lots
entry.content:
Just for the record - you are talking about Inspection Points, not Inspection Lot as indicated in your request, correct? App F2689 is about inspection points.

I bet you are a victim of the restriction which only applies to the app but not for the GUI - the Inspection Point Field combination you use in the routing header must not contain anything else than date and time. We had defined our own, which has a 3rd field in the combination and asks in the GUI for the field to complete before the inspection starts, but in the app you just don't see that inspection lot.

Can you share which is your Inspection Point Field in the Routing header? If you use 101 (date/time) it should work, might be worth a try.

Note: this only applies to S/4HANA On Premise / Private Cloud. In the Public Cloud, the SAP help shows that this restriction does not apply anymore, there is more possible.

entry.title: Troubleshooting SAP Analytics Cloud (SAC) Access Errors for BW Live Data in Microsoft Edge
entry.content:
Introduction

SAP Analytics Cloud (SAC) provides powerful real-time analytics through BW Live connections. However, users frequently face access issues when opening BW Live stories in Microsoft Edge.

In most cases, these problems are not caused by BW or SAC models, but by:

  • Browser security restrictions in Microsoft Edge
  • Missing SAC or BW roles
  • Incomplete user profile or license assignment

This guide focuses only on BW Live access issues in Microsoft Edge and how to resolve them.

 

  1. Common SAC Access Errors for BW Live Users
  2. Missing User Profile or Role (BW Live Context)

Typical message:
‚ÄúPlease contact your administrator to assign the required role.‚Äù

What it means:

  • Your SAC user profile is not created, or
  • Your SAC license is missing, or
  • Required BW Live‚Äìrelated roles are not assigned

Without these, BW Live stories will not open, even if import models work.

Action:

  • Confirm SAC license assignment
  • Confirm BW Live access role with your administrator

 

  1. Browser Authorization Prompt in Microsoft Edge

What you see:

  • Microsoft Edge asks for username and password when opening a BW Live story

What it means:

  • User profile creation has started
  • SAC license is not yet fully assigned

This issue is more visible in BW Live stories, because they require live authentication.

Action:

  • Wait for license completion
  • Check request status with the administrator

 

  1. Unauthorized Error Due to IDM Lock (BW Live)

Typical error:

  • ‚ÄúUnauthorized‚Äù
  • SAML2 authentication error

What it means:

  • Your SAP user ID is locked in Identity Management (IDM)
  • BW Live authentication fails immediately

Action:

  • Contact administrator
  • Request IDM unlock

 

  1. BW Live Connection Fails in Microsoft Edge

Typical symptoms:

  • BW Live story opens but data does not load
  • ‚ÄúUnable to connect to BW system‚Äù
  • Blank tables or charts

Most common root cause in Edge:

  • Third-party cookies are blocked

This issue affects BW Live only, not import models.

 

  1. Microsoft Edge Settings Required for BW Live

Third-Party Cookies (Critical for BW Live)

Microsoft Edge may automatically disable third-party cookies every 90 days.

When this happens:

  • BW Live authentication fails
  • SAC stories stop working suddenly

 

How to Enable Third-Party Cookies in Edge

  1. Open a BW Live SAC story in Microsoft Edge
  2. Look for the eye symbol in the browser address bar
  3. Click the eye symbol
  4. Enable third-party cookies for the SAC site
  5. Refresh the page

In most cases, BW Live data loads immediately.

 

  1. Pop-Ups and Redirects (BW Live Requirement)

BW Live uses pop-ups for:

  • Authentication
  • Variable prompts

If pop-ups are blocked, BW Live cannot complete login.

Edge Configuration

  1. Go to Edge Settings
  2. Open Cookies and Site Permissions
  3. Select Pop-ups and redirects
  4. Add your SAC tenant URL to Allow

Reload the BW Live story after this change.

  1. Role-Based Access for BW Live Data

If SAC opens but BW Live data fails:

Possible reason:

  • Missing BW Live‚Äìspecific role or view authorization

Action:

  • Ask administrator to raise a GRC request
  • Ensure both:
    • SAC role
    • BW Live / BW authorization role
      are included

 

Checking GRC Request Status

  1. Open GRC Home
  2. Navigate to Search Requests
  3. Track approval and completion

Do not rely only on email updates.

 

  1. Confirmation That BW Live Access Is Ready

You will receive an email from the SAP Authorization Batch system when:

  • SAC license is assigned
  • User profile is created
  • BW Live roles are active

After this, BW Live stories should open correctly in Microsoft Edge.

 

Final Tips for BW Live Users on Microsoft Edge

  • This guide applies only to BW Live data
  • Import models are usually not affected
  • Microsoft Edge needs periodic cookie checks
  • Pop-ups must be allowed
  • Both SAC and BW roles are mandatory

Checking browser settings first can save hours of troubleshooting.

 

Conclusion

Most SAC access errors for BW Live users in Microsoft Edge are caused by browser security settings or missing roles, not by BW or SAC issues. With the right Edge configuration and proper role assignment, BW Live stories work reliably and smoothly.

entry.title: SAP Analytics Cloud Scripting ‚Äì My Practical Learnings (Part 1 of 2)
entry.content:
Introduction

While working with BW Live stories in SAP Analytics Cloud Advanced Mode, I learned that scripting must be defensive, explicit, and user-driven.
In this blog, I share the first three scripting learnings that consistently worked in real projects.

All examples below are error-free and production-safe.

 

  1. Always Convert Text Input Values Explicitly

Learning

Text Input widgets always return strings.
Using them directly in calculations or BW variables leads to errors.

Explicit conversion is mandatory.

 

Working Script Example

// Read value from Text Input

var inputValue = InputField_1.getValue();

 

// Convert string to number safely

var numericValue = ConvertUtils.stringToNumber(inputValue);

Why this works

  • No implicit type conversion
  • No runtime errors
  • Fully supported in SAC

 

  1. Keep User Input Simple, Convert Units in Script

Learning

Business users prefer entering simple numbers, such as millions.
BW Live variables expect full numeric values.

The script must handle the conversion.

 

Working Script Example

// Convert million value to full amount and feed BW variable

Table_Main.getDataSource()

    .setVariableValue("VAR_COST_MIN", numericValue * 1000000);

Benefits

  • Clean user experience
  • Accurate BW filtering
  • No confusion for business users

 

  1. Refresh BW Live Data Only After Setting Variables

Learning

BW Live does not automatically refresh after variable updates.
Refreshing too early or multiple times causes inconsistent behavior.

Always refresh once, after all variables are set.

 

Working Script Example

// Refresh BW Live data after variable assignment

Table_Main.getDataSource().refreshData();

Best Practice

  • One refresh per Execute button
  • Never refresh inside loops

 

Conclusion ‚Äì Part 1

These three learnings form the foundation of stable BW Live scripting:

  • Explicit conversion
  • User-friendly units
  • Controlled refresh

In Part 2, I will cover advanced but safe patterns for helper tables and dynamic filtering.

entry.title: SAP Analytics Cloud Scripting ‚Äì My Practical Learnings (Part 2 of 2)
entry.content:
Introduction

After mastering input handling and refresh control, the next challenge in BW Live is dynamic filtering based on measure values.

Direct measure filtering is limited, so I learned to use helper tables with result set logic. The patterns below are stable and production-safe.

 

  1. Use Helper Tables to Filter Based on Measure Values

Learning

SAC does not allow direct measure-based filters easily.
A helper table can read result sets and drive intelligent filtering.

 

Working Script Example

// Get helper table data source

var dsSource = Table_Helper.getDataSource();

 

// Read result set

var rs = dsSource.getResultSet();

This works reliably after data is loaded.

 

  1. Always Handle Zero and Blank Measure Values Safely

Learning

Zero or blank values distort charts and trends.
They must be filtered carefully without breaking the story.

 

Working Script Example

// Create array for valid dimension members

var dimList = ArrayUtils.create(Type.string);

 

for (var i = 0; i < rs.length; i++) {

 

    var dimObj = rs[i]["DIM_KEY"];

    var measObj = rs[i]["@MeasureDimension"];

 

    if (measObj !== null &&

        measObj.formattedValue !== "0" &&

        measObj.formattedValue !== "") {

 

        dimList.push(dimObj.id);

    }

}

Why this is safe

  • No undefined access
  • Handles blank and zero values
  • Works for BW Live

 

  1. Always Handle the ‚ÄúNo Valid Data‚Äù Scenario

Learning

If no valid records exist, filters must be removed.
Otherwise, users see empty or broken visuals.

 

Working Script Example

var dsTarget = Table_Main.getDataSource();

 

if (dimList.length > 0) {

    dsTarget.setDimensionFilter("DIM_KEY", dimList);

} else {

    dsTarget.removeDimensionFilter("DIM_KEY");

}

This guarantees:

  • No stuck filters
  • Predictable behavior

 

Conclusion ‚Äì Part 2

My key takeaway from SAC scripting is simple:

Stable scripts matter more than clever scripts.

By using helper tables, explicit checks, and safe filtering logic, BW Live stories remain fast, reliable, and easy to maintain.

entry.title: Announcement Regarding Unsupported Business Rule in Sap SuccessFactors
entry.content:
Introduction

This Blog is to notify the SAP Community of an Unsupported Business Rule "Has Incomplete Forms"  which will be removed in the Upcoming Product Feature Release Cycle.

Unsupported Business Rule:

During a recent exploration of potential workarounds for a client requirement to send automated Reminders for Overdue Performance Forms, I came across the business rule ‚ÄúHas Incomplete Forms in Inbox‚Äù which I felt would solve the purpose of Identifying the Overdue Forms in the Inbox of the Employee/Managers/HR. However, during testing, the rule did not function as expected which was confirmed by the Rule Trace. Additionally, I was unable to locate any official documentation for this rule in the SAP Help Portal and Official Documentations from SAP.

I escalated the issue to the SAP Product Team by raising a Ticket, who reviewed it with the Product Engineering team and confirmed that this business rule is no longer supported and will be removed in the upcoming Product Feature Release.

If you are currently using this rule or have configurations dependent on it, please be aware that it may not work correctly and will not be available going forward. It is recommended to review your setup and plan any necessary adjustments ahead of the release. This is a very rare business rule, and I highly doubt if anyone is using it currently, However Community needs to be informed for changes / deprecations in advance, so the configurations are reviewed, and any necessary change management is planned well ahead rather than last minute rush.

Attaching the Confirmation from the SAP Product Team

Conclusion


I hope this update helps you avoid potential issues in your configurations and ensures a smooth transition ahead of the upcoming release. If anyone has questions, feel free to ask‚Äîthis could benefit the wider community as we adapt to this change. In case you are wondering how this has been achieved without the above-mentioned Business Rule, please do check out my Other Blog attached below

Recurring Automated Reminders for Over Due Steps -... - SAP Community

entry.title: Re: Sort a Chart by Variance via Script in SAC
entry.content:
Sorting by Variance created directly in the chart is not supported via scripting in SAP Analytics Cloud.
The sortByValue() method works only with real measures and not with visual comparisons like Actual versus Plan.
Chart quick menu sorting works because it is handled at the user interface level and not by the scripting API.
As a workaround, create Variance as a calculated measure in the BW query or SAC model.
Once it exists as a real measure, it can be sorted using sortByValue().

entry.title: Re: Add a Ameasure to a numeric point chart using script...
entry.content:
In SAP Analytics Cloud, a numeric point accepts only measures, not dimension members like Account.
addMember() is meant for dimensions, so it adds Account as a category, not as a measure.
To add a measure, you must use the measures dimension with addMeasure() on the Value Axis.
Example (working approach):

Chart_1.getDataSource().addMeasure("Revenue");

You cannot add an Account node directly as a numeric point unless it is exposed as a measure in the model or BW query.

entry.title: Re: How to set SAC chart tooltip values using script
entry.content:
This is a known limitation in SAP Analytics Cloud when using Input Dimension Control.
When the dimension is changed dynamically, the tooltip shows only the member value and not the dimension name.
Tooltips are handled at the visual layer and cannot be modified or refreshed through scripting.
There is no API available to force the tooltip to display the current dimension name.
A practical workaround is to show the selected dimension name in a Text widget and update it using script.

entry.title: Re: SAC date filters
entry.content:
This cannot be achieved fully using a single Story-level date filter due to model and calculation limitations in SAP Analytics Cloud.
Story filters always pass a date range, but measures using RESTRICT or rolling logic expect a single month and will fail when multiple periods are passed.
There is no supported way to dynamically convert a Story date range into a single month for selected measures.
The practical workaround is to keep a Story filter for range-based metrics and control single-month metrics using page-level filters or scripting.
For usability, show the refresh date and applied logic clearly using Text widgets, which is the SAP-recommended design approach.

entry.title: Re: How to maintain documentation for data elements on Cl...
entry.content:
Hello Daniel,

Data element long texts are displayed by default in UI5 (Fiori) apps in SAP S/4HANA Public Cloud Edition, regardless of type (standard or custom).

To create data element long texts, run transaction SE11 in the relevant ABAP backend, search for a data element, edit it, click Documentation, enter your text, save and release your changes:

The texts will then be displayed in the SAP Companion Help Panel and on the app UI when you click the question mark next to a field. This is also supported in WalkMe.

Please note that you can already check your texts before releasing your transport request by entering the app ID in the transaction field in the backend:

Hope this answers your question.

Best regards,

Francesco

entry.title: Re: Is there a practice system for learning SAP Business Data Cloud?
entry.content:
Hi @Yogananda  @MarkyMark Why does free trial has so many restriction?

The SAP BDC free trial has significant limitations that make hands-on learning extremely difficult. For example:

  • You cannot create data products that can be shared with Databricks

  • Space creation authorization is restricted

  • BW PCE is not available

  • Cant install new app

These restrictions prevent users from practicing many of the new and important features of the platform.

This raises a key concern:
How are individuals supposed to learn and build real skills if they do not have access to a system through their employer?

If full capabilities cannot be offered for free, there should at least be a simple, self-service paid option for individuals. Currently, even paid access often requires:

  • Being an SAP Partner, or

  • Having an employer purchase the system first

As a result, individuals who want to invest in learning on their own are effectively blocked.

With so many restrictions, the trial system defeats its own purpose. A trial should enable users to explore and practice most of the platform‚Äôs key and newly released features , not limit them to a subset that provides only theoretical exposure.

entry.title: Do you know how much you are printing?
entry.content:
As you are surely aware, the on-prem print solution SAP Interactive Forms by Adobe (IFbA) runs on a SAP NetWeaver Application Server Java and it is precisely this Java server that will go out of Mainstream Maintenance at the end of 2027 and out of Extended Maintenance at the end of 2030.

The maintenance strategy for SAP NetWeaver is documented here: https://pages.community.sap.com/topics/abap/netweaver-maintenance-strategy 

 

Successor On-Premise Solution

SAP HANA Extended Application Services, Advanced Model (XSA) will be the successor platform for Adobe Document Services (ADS).

SAP plans to deliver this option Q1, 2027. Customers can decide to switch from the ADS on NetWeaver AS Java to SAP Forms service by Adobe or the ADS on XSA. This guarantees long-term support of Adobe-based forms functionality for S/4 HANA on-premise solutions.

If you decide to switch from your existing on-premise SAP NetWeaver solution to the cloud service SAP Forms service by Adobe it might be interesting to know how much you are currently printing. Because the pricing model in the cloud differs from on-premise.

Pricing Model

The main concept is billable requests. So when you send a technical request to the ADS to generate a form it also involves a billable request. But a billable request is not quite the same as a technical request. So if I send one technical request to generate a pdf comprising 25 pages that is 5 billable requests, because 5 pages is one billable request. If you set a digital signature, it‚Äôs a billable request. If you do a print preview it‚Äôs a billable request and we don‚Äôt distinguish between interactive and print form cause they both generate a load on the ADS and we don‚Äôt distinguish between system type so whether you‚Äôre dealing with a quality system or a productive system or a development system it still generates a load on the ADS and so it costs money. The licensing options can be found in the SAP Discovery Center. The cheapest one is known as the BTPEA. BTP Enterprise Agreement. There is another option which is more flexible but generally more expensive known as Pay-as-you-Go.

Price Estimation

Customers can log render calls via settings in NW AS JAVA.

Collect Data: For the analysis, Python* can be used or the following dedicated ABAP report:

2714231 - IFbA: Configuration for collecting ADS performance data - SAP for Me .

Please pay special attention to section IV in the note.

Analyze Collected Data: 

3690131 - Improve Stability for FP_ADS_PERF_LOG_ANALYZER - SAP for Me

*Python can be executed directly at the operating system level (Linux / Windows) and can read the native file system.

Picture 1: Analyze collected data, display in Table, calculate directly or export to Excel

Picture 2: Calculate Form Request

NOTE: Form requests shown are estimates only based on the usage logs and do not constitute a quote or an offer by SAP.
Whilst every care is taken to ensure the information is correct, no responsibility is accepted by SAP for its accuracy.
Contact SAP if you need assistance or additional information on pricing. 

Q&A regarding the reports:

Q: How long should the log ideally run, is 1 week sufficient?

A: If you want to know how much is generated in a week, the logs should run for a week.

Q: How large will the log file be; do we need to implement special measures for storing the log?

A: There are no explicit recommendations for the tool; around 10MB per file should be fine. Log rotation should be used for storage, as this creates new log files when the 10MB limit has been reached.

Q: What would be the best method to transport all the log files to the "analysis system"?

A: Dependent on the analysis tool. ABAP requires the upload of files / ZIP via SAPGUI

For very large amounts of data (> 1GB), Python should be faster/more efficient.

NOTE: This method is a workaround. No guarantee as to the accuracy or completeness of the resulting outcomes.

See more information on pricing: SAP Discovery Center.
